alert.note: Alert for Newaygo (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 08 at 12:10PM EDT until April 10 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Grand Rapids
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Michigan... Grand River near Comstock Park affecting Kent County. Grand River at Grand Rapids affecting Kent County. Grand River at Robinson Township affecting Ottawa County. Grand River at Ada affecting Kent County. Grand River at Lowell affecting Kent County. Grand River at Ionia affecting Ionia County. Thornapple River Above Hastings affecting Barry County. Thornapple River Near Caledonia affecting Kent County. Maple River at Maple Rapids affecting Clinton County. Muskegon River at Bridgeton affecting Newaygo County. Muskegon River at Newaygo affecting Newaygo County. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Michigan... Red Cedar River At East Lansing affecting Ingham County. Kalamazoo River at New Richmond affecting Allegan County. .Water from heavy rains earlier in the week continues to move down the rivers in West Michigan. The crest on the Grand River is expected to pass through the Grand Rapids area this weekend. For many points along the Grand River, this crest is slightly lower than the crest of May 2020. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL MONDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Muskegon River at Newaygo. * WHEN...Until Monday evening. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, The river starts exceeding its banks and minor flooding begins in low lying areas along the river. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Monday afternoon and continue falling to 9.5 feet next week Saturday. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.3 feet on 04/19/2019. - weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/grr.
